questions.question: According to the NEC, what does 'accessible (as applied to equipment)' mean?
options: Capable of being reached quickly without tools
Capable of being reached for operation, renewal, and inspection
Located within 6 feet of the floor
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, 'accessible (as applied to equipment)' means capable of being reached for operation, renewal, and inspection.

questions.question: What does 'readily accessible' mean per the NEC?
options: Within reach without tools or climbing
Capable of being reached quickly without using tools (other than keys), climbing over obstacles, or using ladders
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, 'readily accessible' means capable of being reached quickly for operation, renewal, or inspection without requiring tools (other than keys), climbing, or using ladders.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'ampacity' according to the NEC?
options: The maximum voltage a conductor can handle
The maximum current a conductor can carry continuously under conditions of use without exceeding its temperature rating
The size of a conductor in AWG
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, ampacity is the maximum current, in amperes, that a conductor can carry continuously under the conditions of use without exceeding its temperature rating.

questions.question: What is the NEC definition of 'approved'?
options: Acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, 'approved' means acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction (AHJ).

questions.question: An arc-fault circuit interrupter (AFCI) is designed to provide protection from what?
options: Effects of arc faults by recognizing characteristics unique to arcing
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, an AFCI is a device intended to provide protection from the effects of arc faults by recognizing characteristics unique to arcing and functioning to de-energize the circuit when an arc fault is detected.

questions.question: What constitutes a 'bathroom' per the NEC definition?
options: An area including a sink with one or more of the following: toilet, urinal, tub, shower, bidet, or similar plumbing fixtures
Any area where personal hygiene occurs
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a bathroom is an area including a sink with one or more of the following: a toilet, a urinal, a tub, a shower, a bidet, or similar plumbing fixtures.

questions.question: What does 'bonded (bonding)' mean according to the NEC?
options: Connected to establish electrical continuity and conductivity
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, 'bonded (bonding)' means connected to establish electrical continuity and conductivity.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a bonding conductor or bonding jumper?
options: To carry fault current to the utility
To ensure the required electrical conductivity between metal parts required to be electrically connected
To provide a path for neutral current
To connect the grounding electrode to earth
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a bonding conductor (bonding jumper) is a conductor that ensures the required electrical conductivity between metal parts that are required to be electrically connected.

questions.question: Each multiwire branch circuit must have a means to do what to all ungrounded conductors?
options: Simultaneously disconnect them at the origin point
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.4(B), each multiwire branch circuit shall be provided with a means that will simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded conductors at the point where the branch circuit originates.

questions.question: What loads can multiwire branch circuits supply according to 210.4(C)?
options: Line-to-neutral loads only, with limited exceptions
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.4(C), multiwire branch circuits shall supply only line-to-neutral loads, with exceptions for equipment with line-to-line loads when all ungrounded conductors are opened simultaneously.

questions.question: In dwelling units, what is the maximum voltage permitted between conductors supplying luminaires?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.6(A), in dwelling units and guest rooms, the voltage shall not exceed 120 volts, nominal, between conductors that supply the terminals of luminaires.

questions.question: Where is GFCI protection required in dwelling unit garages?
options: For all 125-250V receptacles supplied by single-phase branch circuits rated 150V or less to ground
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A)(2), GFCI protection is required for all 125-250V receptacles in garages supplied by single-phase branch circuits rated 150 volts or less to ground.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for receptacles in crawl spaces at or below grade level. What is the purpose?
options: To protect personnel from electric shock in potentially wet locations
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A), GFCI protection is required in crawl spaces at or below grade level to protect personnel from electric shock hazards in potentially damp environments.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for receptacles within what distance from the top inside edge of a sink?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A)(9), GFCI protection is required where receptacles are installed within 6 feet (1.8m) from the top inside edge of the bowl of the sink.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required for receptacles within what distance from a bathtub or shower stall?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A)(11), GFCI protection is required where receptacles are installed within 6 feet (1.8m) of the outside edge of the bathtub or shower stall.

questions.question: GFCI protection is now required in which area of dwelling units according to NEC 2026?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A)(12), GFCI protection is required for receptacles in laundry areas of dwelling units.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of system grounding per NEC 250.4(A)(1)?
options: To limit voltage from lightning, line surges, or unintentional contact with higher-voltage lines and stabilize voltage to earth
To provide a return path for current
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.4(A)(1), electrical systems that are grounded shall be connected to earth so that voltage imposed by lightning, line surges, or unintentional contact with higher-voltage lines is limited and voltage to earth is stabilized during normal operation.

questions.question: Can the earth be considered as an effective ground-fault current path?
options: Yes, if soil resistivity is low
No, the earth shall not be considered an effective ground-fault current path
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.4(A)(5)(c), the earth shall not be considered as an effective ground-fault current path.

questions.question: What connection method is NOT permitted for grounding and bonding equipment per NEC 250.8(B)?
options: Connection devices depending solely on solder
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.8(B), connection devices or fittings that depend solely on solder shall not be used for grounding and bonding connections.

questions.question: Nonconductive coatings on equipment to be grounded must be removed from what areas?
options: Threads and other contact surfaces to ensure electrical continuity
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.12, nonconductive coatings (such as paint, lacquer, and enamel) on equipment to be grounded shall be removed from threads and other contact surfaces to ensure electrical continuity.

questions.question: An AC system of less than 50 volts must be grounded if the transformer supply system exceeds what voltage to ground?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.20(A)(1), AC systems of less than 50 volts shall be grounded if supplied by transformers and the transformer supply system exceeds 150 volts to ground.

questions.question: What is required for ungrounded AC systems operating at 120 volts or more and 1000 volts or less?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.21(B)(1), ungrounded AC systems operating at not less than 120 volts and at 1000 volts or less shall have ground detectors installed on the system.

questions.question: Ungrounded systems must be marked with what warning?
options: 'Caution: Ungrounded System Operating — ___ Volts Between Conductors'
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.21(C), ungrounded systems shall be legibly marked 'Caution: Ungrounded System Operating — ___ Volts Between Conductors' at the source or first disconnecting means.

questions.question: Where must the grounding electrode conductor be connected for a service-supplied AC system?
options: At the service disconnecting means only
At any accessible point from the load end of the service conductors to the service disconnecting means
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.24(A)(1), the grounding electrode conductor connection shall be made at any accessible point from the load end of the service conductors to the terminal or bus to which the grounded service conductor is connected at the service disconnecting means.

questions.question: Type NM cable is permitted for use in which type of building construction?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.10, Type NM and Type NMC cables are permitted in one- and two-family dwellings and multifamily dwellings of Types III, IV, and V construction.

questions.question: Type NM cable is NOT permitted to be used in which location?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.12(A)(4), Type NM cables shall not be used in wet or damp locations.

questions.question: Type NM cable passing through a floor must be enclosed in protection extending at least how high above the floor?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.15(B), where passing through a floor, Type NM cable shall be enclosed in protection extending at least 6 inches (150mm) above the floor.

questions.question: What is the minimum bending radius for Type NM cable?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.24, the radius of the curve of the inner edge of any bend during or after installation shall not be less than five times the diameter of the cable.

questions.question: Type NM cable must be secured within what distance of every cable entry into an enclosure?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.30, nonmetallic-sheathed cable shall be secured within 300mm (12 inches) of every cable entry into enclosures such as outlet boxes, junction boxes, cabinets, or fittings.

questions.question: Type NM cable must be supported at intervals not exceeding what distance?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.30, nonmetallic-sheathed cable shall be supported at intervals not exceeding 1.4m (4-1/2 feet).

questions.question: The 90°C rating of Type NM cable conductors can be used for what purpose?
options: Ampacity adjustment and correction calculations only, with final ampacity not exceeding 60°C rating
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.80, the 90°C (194°F) rating of NM cable conductors may be used for ampacity adjustment and correction calculations, provided the final calculated ampacity does not exceed that of a 60°C rated conductor.

questions.question: For general motor applications, what values are used to determine conductor ampacity?
options: Values from NEC Tables 430.247-430.250 instead of nameplate values
questions.explanation: Per NEC 430.6(A)(1), values given in Tables 430.247-430.250 shall be used instead of the actual current rating marked on the motor nameplate to determine conductor ampacity, switch ratings, and branch-circuit protection.

questions.question: What motor nameplate information is used to determine separate motor overload protection?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 430.6(A)(2), the motor nameplate current ratings shall be used to determine the values for separate motor overload protection.

questions.question: Code letters on motor nameplates indicate what characteristic?
options: Motor input with locked rotor (kVA per horsepower)
questions.explanation: Per NEC 430.7(B), code letters marked on motor nameplates show motor input with locked rotor in kilovolt-amperes per horsepower.

questions.question: A motor controller must be marked with the manufacturer's name, voltage, current or horsepower rating, and what else?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 430.8, a motor controller shall be marked with the manufacturer's name or identification, the voltage, the current or horsepower rating, the short-circuit current rating, and other necessary data.

questions.question: Article 517 applies to electrical installations in what type of facilities?
options: Health care facilities that provide services to human beings
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.1, Article 517 applies to electrical construction and installation criteria in health care facilities that provide services to human beings.

questions.question: In health care patient care spaces, what type of wiring method provides an effective ground-fault current path?
options: Metal raceway system, or cable with metallic armor or sheath that qualifies as an equipment grounding conductor
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.13(A), branch circuits serving patient care spaces shall be provided with an effective ground-fault current path by installation in a metal raceway system or a cable having a metallic armor or sheath assembly that qualifies as an equipment grounding conductor.

questions.question: In patient care spaces, what size insulated copper conductor is required to connect equipment grounding terminal buses of normal and essential branch-circuit panelboards?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.14, the equipment grounding terminal buses of normal and essential branch-circuit panelboards serving the same individual patient care vicinity shall be connected together with an insulated continuous copper conductor not smaller than 10 AWG.

questions.question: Are isolated ground receptacles permitted within the patient care vicinity?
options: No, isolated ground receptacles shall not be installed within a patient care vicinity
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.16(A), an isolated ground receptacle shall not be installed within a patient care vicinity.

questions.question: When is a second level of ground-fault protection of equipment (GFPE) required in health care facilities?
options: When GFPE is applied at the service supplying the facility
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.17, if ground-fault protection of equipment (GFPE) is applied to the service supplying a health care facility with Category 1 spaces, an additional level of ground-fault protection is required downstream.

questions.question: What is the minimum overhead conductor clearance from the water level of a swimming pool for 0-15kV conductors?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 680.9(A), for conductors 0 through 15kV, the minimum clearance in any direction to the water level or edge of water surface is 25 feet (7.5m).

questions.question: What is the horizontal limit of clearance from the inside wall of a pool for overhead conductors?
options: 10 feet minimum, extending to outer edge of diving structures
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 680.9(A), the horizontal limit of clearance measured from inside wall of the pool shall extend to the outer edge of structures but not less than 10 feet (3m).

questions.question: Underground wiring within what horizontal distance from the inside wall of a pool is permitted?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.11(A), underground wiring within 5 feet (1.5m) horizontally from the inside wall of the pool is permitted using approved wiring methods.

questions.question: Pool maintenance disconnecting means must be located not less than what distance horizontally from the inside walls of a pool?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.13, the maintenance disconnecting means shall be located not less than 5 feet (1.5m) horizontally from the inside walls of a pool, spa, fountain, or hot tub unless separated by a permanent barrier.

questions.question: What wiring method is NOT considered suitable for corrosive pool environments?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.14(A), aluminum conduit and tubing wiring methods shall not be permitted in corrosive pool environments.

questions.question: For a permanently installed pool, the maximum length for a flexible cord connecting fixed equipment is what?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.8(A), for other than storable pools, the flexible cord connecting fixed or stationary equipment shall not exceed 3 feet (900mm) in length.

questions.question: Feeders and branch circuits in a corrosive pool environment must contain an EGC that is what?
options: Insulated copper conductor not smaller than 12 AWG
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.7(A), feeders and branch circuits installed in a corrosive environment or wet location shall contain an EGC that is an insulated copper conductor sized per Table 250.122, but not smaller than 12 AWG.

questions.question: Article 700 applies to what type of electrical systems?
options: Emergency systems for illumination, power, or both when the normal supply is interrupted
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.1, Article 700 applies to the electrical safety of emergency systems consisting of circuits and equipment intended to supply, distribute, and control electricity for illumination, power, or both when the normal electrical supply is interrupted.

questions.question: Reconditioned transfer switches are permitted to be installed in emergency systems. True or False?
options: False, reconditioned transfer switches shall not be installed
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.3, reconditioned transfer switches shall not be installed in emergency systems.

questions.question: Emergency system equipment must be maintained in accordance with what?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.4(C), emergency system equipment shall be maintained in accordance with manufacturer instructions and industry standards.

questions.question: If an emergency system relies on a single alternate source, what must be provided for maintenance of that source?
options: Permanent switching means to connect a portable or temporary alternate source
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.4(F), if the emergency system relies on a single alternate source of power that will be disabled for maintenance, the system shall include permanent switching means to connect a portable or temporary alternate source.

questions.question: Emergency system load management must prioritize what type of circuits first?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.5(C), selective load management shall ensure adequate power to circuits in this order of priority: (1) Emergency circuits, (2) Legally required standby circuits, (3) Optional standby circuits.

questions.question: Automatic transfer switches for emergency systems must be what?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.6(B), automatic transfer switches shall be electrically operated and mechanically held.

questions.question: Transfer equipment for emergency systems can supply what type of loads?
options: Emergency and legally required standby loads
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.6(D), transfer equipment shall supply only emergency loads.

questions.question: What must be field marked on the exterior of emergency system transfer equipment?
options: The short-circuit current rating based on the specific OCPD protecting it
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.6(E), the short-circuit current rating of the transfer equipment, based on the specific overcurrent protective device type and settings protecting the transfer equipment, shall be field marked on the exterior.

questions.question: According to NEC Article 100, what does 'automatic' mean?
options: Performing a function without the necessity of human intervention
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, 'automatic' means performing a function without the necessity of human intervention.

questions.question: What is the NEC definition of an 'appliance'?
options: Utilization equipment, generally other than industrial, that is fastened in place or portable and built in standardized sizes to perform one or more functions
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, an appliance is utilization equipment, generally other than industrial, that is fastened in place, stationary, or portable; is normally built in a standardized size or type; and is installed or connected as a unit to perform one or more functions.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'authority having jurisdiction (AHJ)'?
options: An organization, office, or individual responsible for enforcing code requirements or approving equipment
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, the authority having jurisdiction (AHJ) is an organization, office, or individual responsible for enforcing the requirements of a code or standard, or for approving equipment, materials, an installation, or a procedure.

questions.question: What is the NEC definition of a 'battery'?
options: A device that stores chemical energy
A single cell or a group of cells connected together electrically in series, parallel, or both
A rechargeable energy storage device only
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a battery is a single cell or a group of cells connected together electrically in series, in parallel, or a combination of both.

questions.question: What is a 'grounding electrode bonding conductor'?
options: The conductor connecting equipment to the grounding electrode
A conductor, other than the grounding electrode conductor, used to interconnect two or more grounding electrodes to form the grounding electrode system
A conductor connecting the neutral to ground
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a grounding electrode bonding conductor is a conductor, other than the grounding electrode conductor, used to interconnect two or more grounding electrodes to form the grounding electrode system.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'main bonding jumper'?
options: To connect building steel to the grounding electrode
To provide the connection between the grounded circuit conductor and the equipment grounding conductor at the service
To bond water pipes to the electrical system
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a main bonding jumper is a component of the effective ground-fault current path that is the connection between the grounded circuit conductor and the equipment grounding conductor, or the supply-side bonding conductor, or both, at the service equipment.

questions.question: What is a 'supply-side bonding jumper'?
options: A jumper on the utility side of the meter
A conductor installed on the supply side of a service or within service equipment that ensures electrical conductivity between metal parts
A bonding jumper at the transformer
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a supply-side bonding jumper is a component of the effective ground-fault current path installed on the supply side of a service or within a service equipment enclosure(s) that ensures the required electrical conductivity between metal parts.

questions.question: Per NEC 210.8, how is the distance from receptacles measured for GFCI requirements?
options: As the shortest path the power supply cord would follow without piercing a floor, wall, ceiling, or fixed barrier
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8, for GFCI requirements, the distance from receptacles shall be measured as the shortest path the power supply cord connected to the receptacle would follow without piercing a floor, wall, ceiling, or fixed barrier.

questions.question: GFCI-protected receptacles must be installed in what location?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8, the GFCI shall be installed in a readily accessible location.

questions.question: GFCI protection is NOT required for receptacles supplying only what type of system?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A) Exception 2, GFCI protection shall not be required for a receptacle supplying only a permanently installed premises security system.

questions.question: In a 3-phase, 4-wire, delta-connected system with a midpoint grounded, what color must identify the high-leg conductor?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 110.15, the phase conductor with the higher voltage to ground must be permanently marked with an outer finish that is orange or marked orange with another effective marking.

questions.question: The high leg in a delta-connected system must be located in what phase position in panelboards?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 408.10(E)(1), the high leg in delta-connected systems shall be on the B phase.

questions.question: What is the purpose of performing alterations to stop objectionable current per NEC 250.6(B)?
options: To prevent circulating currents on grounding conductors while maintaining the effective ground-fault current path
To isolate electronic equipment from ground
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.6(B), alterations may be made to stop objectionable current while still meeting the requirements for effective ground-fault current path. Alterations include changing locations or discontinuing (but not all) grounding connections.

questions.question: Currents that introduce electromagnetic interference or data errors in electronic equipment are considered objectionable currents per NEC 250.6. True or False?
options: False - these are not considered objectionable currents for purposes of 250.6
questions.explanation: Per NEC 250.6(D), currents that introduce electromagnetic interference or data errors in electronic equipment shall not be considered the objectionable currents addressed in 250.6.

questions.question: Type NMC cable can be used in what type of locations that Type NM cannot?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.10(B), Type NMC cable is permitted for both exposed and concealed work in dry, wet, damp, or corrosive locations.

questions.question: Type NM and NMC cables shall NOT be installed exposed in dropped or suspended ceiling cavities in what occupancies?
options: Other than one-, two-family and multifamily dwellings
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.12(2), Types NM and NMC cables shall not be exposed within a dropped or suspended ceiling cavity in other than one-, two-family and multifamily dwellings.

questions.question: Two-conductor Type NM cable shall not be stapled in what orientation?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.30, flat cables shall not be stapled on edge.

questions.question: The sheath of nonmetallic-sheathed cable must extend how far into an enclosure beyond any cable clamp?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 334.19, the sheath on nonmetallic-sheathed cable shall extend not less than 6mm (1/4 inch) beyond any cable clamp or cable entry inside the enclosure.

questions.question: When using 3-phase, 4-wire, wye-connected systems to supply nonlinear loads, what special consideration must be given?
options: Neutral conductor may carry high harmonic currents
All phases must be the same color
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.4(A) Informational Note No. 1, a 3-phase, 4-wire, wye-connected power system used to supply power to nonlinear loads might necessitate that the power system design allow for the possibility of high harmonic currents on the neutral conductor.

questions.question: What reconditioned equipment is NOT permitted in branch circuits per NEC 210.3?
options: Equipment providing GFCI or AFCI protection
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.3, equipment that provides ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection for personnel and equipment that provides arc-fault circuit-interrupter protection shall not be reconditioned.

questions.question: For dc systems over 60 volts, what color identifies positive polarity conductors 6 AWG or smaller?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.5(C)(3)(a), positive polarity dc conductors 6 AWG or smaller shall be identified by a continuous red outer finish or red stripe, among other options.

questions.question: For dc systems over 60 volts, what color identifies negative polarity conductors 6 AWG or smaller?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.5(C)(3)(b), negative polarity dc conductors 6 AWG or smaller shall be identified by a continuous black outer finish or black stripe, among other options.

questions.question: Luminaires without lampholders are now covered under what voltage limitation section?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.6(C)(6), circuits not exceeding 277 volts to ground are permitted to supply luminaires without lampholders, such as luminaires with nonserviceable LEDs.

questions.question: GFCI protection is required in indoor damp and wet locations in dwelling units. True or False?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.8(A)(13) and (14), GFCI protection is required for receptacles in indoor damp locations and indoor wet locations in dwelling units.

questions.question: What is the term for a conductor used to connect the system grounded conductor to a grounding electrode?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, a grounding electrode conductor (GEC) is a conductor used to connect the system grounded conductor or the equipment to a grounding electrode.

questions.question: What is the maximum current a Class A GFCI will allow before tripping?
questions.explanation: Type-A (Class A) GFCIs operate on fault currents ranging from 4 to 6 milliamperes or more.

questions.question: For voltages above 150 volts to ground but not exceeding 480 volts at pools, what type of GFCI protection is required?
options: SPGFCI not to exceed 20mA ground-fault trip current
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.5(C), ground-fault protection of receptacles and outlets on branch circuits operating at voltages above 150 volts to ground shall be provided with SPGFCI protection not to exceed 20-mA ground-fault trip current.

questions.question: Terminals used for bonding and equipment grounding at pools shall be identified for use in what environment?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.7(C), terminals used for bonding and equipment grounding shall be identified for use in wet locations.

questions.question: Electric pool water heaters with resistive elements shall have heating elements subdivided into loads not exceeding what amperage?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.10(A)(1), all electric pool water heaters incorporating resistive heating elements shall have the heating elements subdivided into loads not exceeding 48 amperes and protected at not over 60 amperes.

questions.question: At least one GFCI-protected receptacle is required in what pool-related location?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.12(B)(1), at least one GFCI-protected 125-volt, 15- or 20-ampere receptacle shall be located within an equipment room.

questions.question: What is the minimum communication cable clearance above the maximum water level of a swimming pool?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.9(B), communications, radio, and television coaxial cables shall be permitted at a height of not less than 10 feet (3.0m) above the maximum water level.

questions.question: Underground wiring shall not be permitted under the pool unless what condition is met?
options: It is necessary to supply pool equipment permitted by Article 680
It is at least 3 feet below the pool bottom
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.11(B), underground wiring shall not be permitted under the pool unless this wiring is necessary to supply pool equipment permitted by Article 680.

questions.question: Electrical equipment shall not be installed in pool rooms without what feature?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.12(A), electrical equipment shall not be installed in rooms, vaults, or pits that do not have drainage that prevents water accumulation during normal operation or maintenance.

questions.question: For permanently installed pools, what wiring methods are permitted for flexible connections to motors?
options: Liquidtight flexible metal, liquidtight flexible nonmetallic conduit, or MC cable suitable for the use
questions.explanation: Per NEC 680.21(A)(1), where necessary to employ flexible connections at or adjacent to the motor, liquidtight flexible metal, liquidtight flexible nonmetallic conduit, or MC cable suitable for the use shall be permitted.

questions.question: Emergency systems must have adequate capacity per Article 120 (or approved method) and be capable of what?
options: Supplying rapid load changes and transient power requirements
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.5(B), the emergency system capacity shall be sufficient for the rapid load changes and transient power and energy requirements associated with any expected loads.

questions.question: Emergency source(s) shall be permitted to operate in parallel with the normal source under what condition?
options: When the capacity required to supply the emergency load is maintained at all times
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.5(D)(1), the emergency source shall be permitted to operate in parallel with the normal source where the capacity required to supply the emergency load is maintained at all times.

questions.question: Transfer equipment for emergency systems must be designed to prevent what?
options: Inadvertent interconnection of normal and emergency sources
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.6(A), transfer equipment shall be designed and installed to prevent the inadvertent interconnection of normal and emergency sources of supply in any operation of the transfer equipment.

questions.question: Meter-mounted transfer switches are permitted for emergency system use. True or False?
options: False - meter-mounted transfer switches shall not be permitted for emergency system use
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.6(A), meter-mounted transfer switches shall not be permitted for emergency system use.

questions.question: What test is required for emergency systems upon installation?
options: Commissioning witness test conducted or witnessed by the AHJ
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.4(A), the authority having jurisdiction shall conduct or witness the commissioning of the completed system upon installation.

questions.question: Emergency system tests and maintenance records must be made available to whom?
options: Those authorized to design, install, inspect, maintain, and operate the system
questions.explanation: Per NEC 700.4(D), a written or digital record shall be kept of tests and maintenance and made available to those authorized to design, install, inspect, maintain, and operate the system.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'patient care vicinity' in health care facilities?
options: An area 6 feet horizontally in all directions from the bed and 7.5 feet above the floor
Only the area around medical equipment
questions.explanation: The patient care vicinity consists of an area 6 feet horizontally in all directions from the bed and vertically to 7.5 feet above the floor.

questions.question: What exception allows luminaires in patient care spaces without requiring a separate insulated EGC?
options: Luminaires more than 7.5 feet above the floor
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.13 Exception, luminaires more than 2.3m (7.5 feet) above the floor and switches located outside of the patient care vicinity may be connected without a separate insulated EGC.

questions.question: Branch circuits serving life safety lighting and power circuits shall not be part of what type of circuit?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.15, the branch circuit serving life safety lighting and power circuits shall not be part of a multiwire branch circuit.

questions.question: What electrical equipment is covered under Article 517 patient care-related equipment reconditioning exceptions?
options: Patient care-related equipment like MRI, CT, X-ray units
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.3, the reconditioning requirements of the Code do not apply to patient care-related electrical equipment such as MRI, fluoroscopy, CT, and X-ray units, which are regulated under federal requirements.

questions.question: What sources are permitted to supplement the electrical service to a health care facility?
options: Power production source, fuel cell systems, energy storage systems, health care microgrids
questions.explanation: Per NEC 517.4(A), power production source, fuel cell systems, energy storage systems, and health care microgrids are permitted to supplement the service to supply the entire electrical load based on reliability.

accessible equipment.definition: Capable of being reached for operation, renewal, and inspection.

accessible wiring methods.definition: Capable of being removed or exposed without damaging the building structure or finish or not permanently closed in by the structure.

readily accessible.definition: Capable of being reached quickly for operation, renewal, or inspections without requiring those to whom ready access is requisite to use tools (other than keys), to climb over or under obstacles, or to resort to portable ladders.

authority having jurisdiction.definition: An organization, office, or individual responsible for enforcing the requirements of a code or standard, or for approving equipment, materials, an installation, or a procedure.

approved.definition: Acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction.

askarel.definition: A generic term for a group of nonflammable synthetic chlorinated hydrocarbons used as electrical insulating media.

attachment plug.definition: A device that, by insertion in a receptacle, establishes a connection between the conductors of the attached flexible cord and the conductors connected permanently to the receptacle.

automatic.definition: Performing a function without the necessity of human intervention.

bipolar circuit.definition: A dc circuit comprised of two monopole circuits, each having an opposite polarity connected to a common reference point.

bonding conductor.definition: A conductor that ensures the required electrical conductivity between metal parts that are required to be electrically connected.

grounding electrode bonding conductor.definition: A conductor, other than the grounding electrode conductor, used to interconnect two or more grounding electrodes to form the grounding electrode system.

equipment bonding jumper.definition: A component of the effective ground-fault current path that is the connection between two or more portions of the equipment grounding conductor.

main bonding jumper.definition: A component of the effective ground-fault current path that is the connection between the grounded circuit conductor and the equipment grounding conductor at the service equipment.

supply-side bonding jumper.definition: A component of the effective ground-fault current path installed on the supply side of a service or within a service equipment enclosure(s) that ensures the required electrical conductivity between metal parts.

circuit breaker.definition: A device designed to open and close a circuit by nonautomatic means and to open the circuit automatically on a predetermined overcurrent without damage to itself.

concentric knockout.definition: A series of partially cut circular portions of a box wall arranged with a common center point, allowing different size knockouts to be removed.

controller.definition: A device or group of devices that serves to govern the electric power delivered to equipment.

current-carrying conductor.definition: A conductor intended to carry current under normal operation, including phase conductors and the neutral under certain conditions.

effective ground-fault current path.definition: An intentionally constructed, low-impedance electrically conductive path designed to carry fault current from the point of a ground fault to the electrical supply source to facilitate operation of the OCPD.

emergency system.definition: Those systems legally required and classed as emergency by municipal, state, federal, or other codes, intended to automatically supply illumination, power, or both to designated areas and equipment when the normal supply is interrupted.

energized.definition: Electrically connected to, or is, a source of voltage.

exposed wiring.definition: On or attached to the surface or behind panels designed to allow access.

ground detector.definition: A device or system that provides a visual indication, audible signal, or both to alert of a ground-fault condition in an electrical system.

ground fault.definition: An unintentional, electrically conducting connection between an ungrounded conductor of an electrical circuit and the normally non-current-carrying conductors, metallic enclosures, metallic raceways, metallic equipment, or earth.

grounded.definition: Connected (connecting) to ground or to a conductive body that extends the ground connection.

health care facility.definition: Buildings or portions of buildings in which medical, dental, psychiatric, nursing, obstetrical, or surgical care are provided.

high leg.definition: The phase conductor in a 4-wire, 3-phase, delta system with a higher voltage to ground due to the grounded midpoint of one winding. Must be identified orange and located on B phase.

impedance grounded system.definition: A system in which the grounding connection has a resistance or reactance deliberately inserted to limit fault current.

in sight from.term: In Sight From (Within Sight From, Within Sight)
in sight from.definition: Visible and not more than 50 feet (15m) distant from the equipment.

labeled.definition: Equipment or materials to which has been attached a label, symbol, or other identifying mark of an organization acceptable to the AHJ.

listed.definition: Equipment, materials, or services included in a list published by an organization acceptable to the AHJ that maintains periodic inspection of production and states that the equipment meets appropriate designated standards.

lockout/tagout.definition: Safety procedure used to ensure that dangerous machines are properly shut off and not started up again prior to the completion of maintenance or servicing work.

motor control center.definition: An assembly of one or more enclosed sections having a common power bus and principally containing motor control units.

multiwire branch circuit.definition: A branch circuit that consists of two or more ungrounded conductors that have a voltage between them and a grounded conductor that has equal voltage between it and each ungrounded conductor.

neutral conductor.definition: The conductor connected to the neutral point of a system that is intended to carry current under normal conditions.

noncurrent-carrying.definition: Metal parts such as enclosures, raceways, and frames that do not carry current under normal operation but may become energized under fault conditions.

objectionable current.definition: Unwanted current flowing on grounding conductors or bonding paths, typically caused by multiple grounding connections. Does not include currents from normal operation or ground faults.

outlet.definition: A point on the wiring system at which current is taken to supply utilization equipment.

overcurrent.definition: Any current in excess of the rated current of equipment or the ampacity of a conductor, caused by overload, short circuit, or ground fault.

patient care space.definition: Any space of a health care facility wherein patients are intended to be examined or treated.

patient care vicinity.definition: The space with surfaces likely to be contacted by the patient or an attendant touching the patient. Typically defined as 6 feet horizontally and 7.5 feet above the floor from the bed.

permanently installed pool.definition: A pool that is constructed in the ground or partially in the ground, and all pools installed inside a building regardless of construction method.

qualified person.definition: One who has skills and knowledge related to the construction and operation of the electrical equipment and installations and has received safety training to recognize and avoid the hazards involved.

separately derived system.definition: An electrical source, other than a service, having no direct connection(s) to circuit conductors of any other electrical source other than those established by grounding and bonding connections.

short circuit.definition: An abnormal connection of relatively low impedance, whether made accidentally or intentionally, between two points of different potential.

spgfci.definition: A ground-fault protection device for voltages above 150 volts to ground, typically with trip currents up to 20mA, used for pool and similar equipment.

storable pool.definition: A pool that is constructed on or above the surface of the ground and is capable of holding water to a maximum depth of 1 meter (42 inches) or a pool with nonmetallic, molded polymeric walls regardless of dimension.

transfer switch.definition: An automatic or nonautomatic device for transferring one or more load conductor connections from one power source to another.

ungrounded conductor.definition: A conductor that is not grounded or bonded to ground. In a typical branch circuit, the phase or 'hot' conductors are ungrounded.

utilization equipment.definition: Equipment that utilizes electric energy for electronic, electromechanical, chemical, heating, lighting, or similar purposes.

voltage nominal.definition: A nominal value assigned to a circuit or system for the purpose of conveniently designating its voltage class (e.g., 120/240 volts, 480Y/277 volts).

wet location.definition: Installations underground or in concrete slabs or masonry in direct contact with the earth; in locations subject to saturation with water or other liquids; in unprotected locations exposed to weather.
